title: Russia Bondholders Say Debt Default Could Already Be Here; Some investors say that a small interest payment is overdue, which could trigger credit-default swap contracts
text:
The allegedly overdue payment represents interest that Russia accrued while it spent 28 days in a grace period in April and early May, the documents show. The bond in question matured in early April. Russia didn't pay its foreign interest for nearly a month, until an 11th hour payment was made .

However, some bondholders have said that Moscow forgot to include an estimated $1.9 million of accrued interest that was generated in the interim, which is now overdue beyond the grace period, and they have accordingly informed Euroclear, the records show.

Euroclear didn't immediately respond to a request for comment Wednesday. The Russian Embassy in Washington didn't respond to a request for comment.

The size of the alleged interest payments miss is too small to trigger cross-defaults across Russia's outstanding foreign debts, according to a person familiar with the matter. But investors have submitted to Euroclear, the custodian for the foreign-currency bonds, that the missed interest payments should constitute an event of default, the records show.

If it is deemed a default by market participants, that could trigger payments on credit-default swap contracts that act as insurance against bond defaults. Whether the contracts pay out is up to a body that oversees the swap industry and usually needs a payment miss of around $1 million for the claim to be considered valid.

There are about $4.5 billion in credit-default swap contracts that directly reference Russia, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co . research.

Investors have anticipated for some time that debt payments from Moscow would likely stop as Western nations tightened Russia's access to foreign credit. Most of Russia's foreign-currency debts have been trading between 10 cents and 20 cents on the dollar since February when the invasion of Ukraine began.
